subject: Economics
title: Conditional Cash Transfers: Paying People to Invest in Themselves
description: A 60-second lesson on Conditional Cash Transfers: Paying People to Invest in Themselves.

hook.text: Mexico pays poor mothers $65/month â€” but only if their kids attend school and get health checkups. It's not charity.

buildup.text: Conditional cash transfers (CCTs): give money to the poor on the condition they invest in education and health.

discovery.text: Progresa increased school enrollment by 3.4%, reduced illness by 23%, and reduced poverty by 10%.

twist.text: Unconditional transfers (just giving money without conditions) work almost as well in many studies.

climax.text: CCTs work because they address two problems at once.

punchline.text: The smartest welfare program doesn't just fight poverty today.

quiz.question: Why are conditional cash transfers considered a 'two-generation' intervention?
options: Cash addresses immediate poverty for parents while the conditions (school, health) build human capital to prevent poverty in children
